messages.content: Please create a short formative assessment for 3rd-grade science on plant parts and their functions.

I think you want a brief, simple check on plant parts and what they do—though I’m a little unsure if you prefer pictures or just text. Here’s a quick 10–12 minute assessment. If I misunderstood, please tell me and I’ll adjust.

Title: Plant Parts and Functions — Quick Check (Grade 3)
Time: 10–12 minutes
Materials: Pencil; optional highlighters

Instructions: Answer all questions. For the matching section, write the letter of the best answer.

Section A — Multiple Choice (1 point each)
1) Which part of a plant takes in water from the soil?
   A. Leaf   B. Root   C. Flower   D. Fruit

2) The stem’s main job is to:
   A. Make seeds
   B. Hold the plant up and move water/food
   C. Soak up sunlight only
   D. Take in water from the soil

3) Leaves mostly help plants to:
   A. Breathe and make food using sunlight
   B. Store seeds
   C. Anchor the plant to the ground
   D. Attract insects with smells

4) Flowers usually help plants to:
   A. Drink water
   B. Make food
   C. Make seeds
   D. Hold the plant in the soil

Section B — Matching (1 point each)
Match the plant part to its function. Write A, B, C, or D.
Parts:
1) Root
2) Stem
3) Leaf
4) Flower
Functions:
A. Makes seeds and can attract pollinators
B. Takes in water and holds plant in soil
C. Carries water/food and holds the plant up
D. Uses sunlight to make food

Section C — Short Answer (1 point each)
5) Why are roots important to a plant? (Answer in one sentence.)
6) Name one way stems help plants survive. (Answer in one sentence.)

Scoring Guide (10 points total):
- Section A: 4 points (1 point each)
- Section B: 4 points (1 point each)
- Section C: 2 points (1 point each; accept any correct, simple explanation)

Answer Key:
1) B
2) B
3) A
4) C
Matching: 1–B, 2–C, 3–D, 4–A
Short Answer (sample acceptable responses):
- Q5: “Roots take in water and minerals and hold the plant in the soil.”
- Q6: “Stems carry water and food through the plant” or “Stems hold up leaves and flowers to the light.”

I’m not entirely sure if you wanted fewer items or visuals; I can add picture prompts or reduce to 5 questions if that’s better.
I need a simple formative assessment for 3rd grade science on the water cycle. Make it 10 minutes, worth 8 points, and include an answer key.

Title: Grade 3 Science Quick Check – The Water Cycle (10 minutes, 8 points)
Name: __________________  Date: __________
Instructions: Answer all questions. Write clearly.

1) When a puddle dries up on a sunny day, what process is happening?
   A. Precipitation
   B. Evaporation
   C. Condensation
   D. Collection
   (1 point)

2) Water droplets forming on the outside of a cold glass is called:
   A. Evaporation
   B. Condensation
   C. Precipitation
   D. Runoff
   (1 point)

3) Rain, snow, sleet, or hail falling from clouds is:
   A. Evaporation
   B. Condensation
   C. Precipitation
   D. Collection
   (1 point)

4) Most evaporation on Earth happens from:
   A. Oceans
   B. Mountains
   C. Roads
   D. Forests
   (1 point)

5) Fill in the blanks:
   Water vapor cools and changes into tiny drops. This is called ________.
   Those drops fall from clouds to Earth as ________.
   (2 points; 1 point per correct blank)

6) Short answer (1–2 sentences): Why is the sun important to the water cycle?
   (2 points)

Answer Key and Points
1) B (1)
2) B (1)
3) C (1)
4) A (1)
5) condensation; precipitation (2)
6) Sample correct ideas: The sun heats water and causes evaporation; it provides energy that drives the water cycle. (2 if clearly stated; 1 if partially correct)
Provide a simple scoring rubric and define mastery for this quick check.

Scoring Rubric (8 points total)
- 7–8 points: Mastery
  The student correctly identifies water cycle processes and accurately explains the sun’s role using appropriate vocabulary (evaporation, condensation, precipitation).
- 5–6 points: Approaching
  The student shows partial understanding with minor errors or incomplete explanation of the sun’s role.
- 0–4 points: Needs Support
  The student has limited understanding and confuses key terms or cannot explain the sun’s role.

Mastery Definition
- Identifies evaporation, condensation, and precipitation in context with no more than one error on multiple-choice items.
- Accurately completes both blanks in item 5.
- Explains the sun’s role as the energy source that heats water and causes evaporation (item 6).
Offer one student accommodation and one extension activity.

Accommodation
- Provide a visual word bank on the assessment page with small icons: evaporation (sun over water with upward arrows), condensation (cloud forming), precipitation (raindrops). Read directions aloud and allow the student to point to answers before writing.

Extension Activity
- Mini-investigation: Place two identical shallow cups of water in different locations (sunny window vs. shaded area). Predict which will evaporate faster, observe for two days, record changes, and write a 2–3 sentence explanation connecting results to the sun’s energy.
